a01: Quite frankly, I need to take a language class for my degree, but I chose Spanish because it's very applicable to living in the United States. A lot of people speak Spanish and it would be nice to be more able to communicate with people in my community and neighborhood.
a03: I like the freedom to learn at my own pace and honestly, it is easier than an in person class. Language has always been difficult for me so having a way to still learn something without being overwhelmed with an in person class is really cool.
ao5a: It is an online course so there is less immersion in the language, with most of my Spanish experience coming from assignments as opposed to the classwork and dialogue in an in person class.
a06: You are a lot more immersed in the language, with Spanish being the primary language being spoken. This forces you to learn if you want to keep up.
a07: It is a very intense experience, with the presume of learning being very high.
a08: You can get work done at your own pace and revisit problem areas as much as you need, allowing for language acquisition to be more integrated into normal life.
a09: You can skate your way through a lot easier; you can pass the class without learning much functional Spanish.
a10a: You have to show up and be prepared, so staying motivated is a matter of success and failure.
a11: It's a lot more accessible, like people that normally would not take a language class at all would be willing to take an online course.

a01: Initially I signed up to take a language course to fulfill my language requirement for my major, however as time went on I am glad I continued to take a language course because my proficiency has significantly improved. What motivates me to learn an additional language is the opportunities it provides such as learning about different cultures, interacting with others and to overall hear different worldviews.
a03: I chose an online class because the time for the in person class could not work into my schedule.  However, an online class allows me to work and study on my own pace while abiding by the deadlines.
a06: Some positive aspects are you get a hands on learning experience, you learn better through repetition and you can ask questions on the spot.
a07: Some negative aspects are feeling pressured to speak on the spot, having trouble understanding what is happening in the class or being left behind.
a08: Some positive aspects are that most of the work is independent and you can practice a topic alone first, think and ask questions later.
a09: Some negative aspects are procrastinating and the higher potential of missing assignments.
a10a: For me, I find online easier to stay motivated because I have the work that needs to be done laid out in front of me and can anticipate what is next.
a11: I feel less anxious taking an online course in-comparison to a face-to-face course. I can worry more about the work.

a01: I am minoring in Spanish, which is why I'm taking my third Rutgers Spanish class this semester. There were many reasons I wanted to learn Spanish, but the mainly because it's extremely useful a long with I have fun learning and practicing with friends.
a02: I feel like with learning a language, the in person communication is super important. One of the best ways of learning a language is by surrounding yourself by people that can also speak the language well. Online would have taken some of this away from the opportunity.
a06: You see people's hand gestures and other forms of communication that you could potentially miss out on in an online format. You also get to meet/interact with other of your classmates in a way that's much easier than online. I think there's many things that improve when taking an in person Spanish class compared to an online one. For example, if a zoom call cuts out, or is lagging, that could severely mess up your learning as it isn't your first language. Someone learning may need to hear the full sentence through, or have it repeated and a faulty online system won't help.
a07: I can't think of any negative aspects of an in-person Spanish class.
a08: I can't think of any positive aspects of taking an online Spanish class. The majority of my classmates bring their laptops to class anyways, so if the teacher instructs us to look at something we have the resources available.
a09: Pretty much everything I said on the previous page. It just wouldn't flow as well as an in person class. Learning a language is definitely possible online, but it is extremely beneficial to practice in person.
a10a: The sense of actually coming to class, and not just opening my laptop while in bed, already requires a lot more effort. If I'm gonna make that initial effort, I will go all the way.
